content: The "District of Columbia Building Heights Act of 1994" limits the height of buildings in the District of Columbia. The Act regulates building heights in the District of Columbia based on street width and limits the size and height of roof structures. The Act regulates building heights in the District of Columbia based on street width. Roof structures not used for human occupancy may exceed height limits with approval from the Mayor, provided they are fireproof. The Act regulates building heights in the District of Columbia based on street width. Roof structures like towers, domes, or chimneys must be set back from the building walls at a distance equal to their height. The Mayor can waive this requirement if it's overly restrictive or impractical without interfering with the Act's purpose or neighboring exposure. The Act regulates building heights in the District of Columbia based on street width and sets requirements for roof structures like towers, domes, or chimneys. Penalties for violations may increase. The Act regulates building heights in the District of Columbia based on street width and sets requirements for roof structures like towers, domes, or chimneys. Penalties for violations may increase to a maximum of $10,000 per day for general violations and $100,000 per day for violations of injunctions. SEC. 3. INCREASE IN AUTHORITY OF NATIONAL CAPITAL PLANNING COMMISSION TO ENFORCE BUILDING HEIGHT LIMITATIONS. Requiring NCPC Approval for Roof Structures Exceeding General Limitations. Amendment to the Act to regulate building heights in DC includes the National Capital Planning Commission in approval process. The Act providing for park and playground system development in the National Capital is amended to include NCPC approval for roof structures exceeding building height limitations in DC. The Act is amended to allow NCPC approval for building heights exceeding limitations in DC within 45 days of submission. The Act is amended to allow the National Capital Planning Commission (NCPC) or its members to enforce building height limitations in the District of Columbia. The National Capital Planning Commission (NCPC) or its members now have the authority to enforce building height limitations in the District of Columbia, as per the amended Act. The National Capital Planning Commission (NCPC) or its members can now enforce building height restrictions in the District of Columbia at the Commission's expense. The Act regulating building heights in DC has been amended to include this authority. The Act regulating building heights in DC has been amended to include the National Capital Planning Commission or its members enforcing building height restrictions in the District of Columbia. The Act of June 20, 1938 has been amended to allow the National Capital Planning Commission or its members to enforce building height restrictions in the District of Columbia as per the Act of June 6, 1924. The amendments made by this Act will apply to buildings and structures in the District of Columbia for which building permits are issued on or after March 23, 1994.
